page.title: 04LOCAL HISTORY CONTD
page.content: Point was originally erected in 1825 in memory of Sir John Doyle KCB KC who was Lieutenant Governor of Guernsey from 1803 to 1815. It was destroyed by the Germans in 1944 and replaced by the States in 1953. There is also a smaller monument showing the Channel Islands next to it which was erected in 1952 to commemorate the Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II. The original was lost during the Occupation. The Baptist Church was built in 1827, the Methodist later in the century and St Martin de la Bellouse (Belloose) or Beilleuse in 1048. The bell tower of St Martins is slightly east of the centre with a clock facing south. Access to the bells is up a spiral staircase inside. The font inside the south door is the only one which dates from pre-Reformation times in the island and the pulpit is dated 1657.
